citation.article-title: Isolation of a new genus of sulfate-reducing bacteria and description of a new species of this genus, Desulfomicrobium apsheronum gen. nov., sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfomicrobium gen. nov.
Desulfomicrobium (Desul.fo.micro.bium - L. pref. de from; L. n. sulfur sulfur; G. adj. micros small; G. n. bios life; M. L. neut. n. Desulfomicrobium, the sulfur-reducing small life)
The bacteria consist of small rod-like to ellipsoidal cells 0.6-0.9 x 1.3-2.9 μm in size. with rounded ends. solitary or in pairs.
Motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Spores are not formed.
The cell wall has the Gram-negative structure and is negatively stained in the gram reaction.
Obligate anaerobes.
Metabolism is respiratory, and chemoorganoheterotrophic, chemolithoheterotrophic, or chemolithoautotrophic.
Simple organic compounds are incompletely oxidized to acetate and CO2.
In this case sulfates and other oxidized sulfur compounds serve as electron acceptors and are reduced to H2S.
Nitrates and sulfur are not reduced.
Certain species have the ability to obtain energy by fermentative metabolism.
Hydrogenase is usually present.
Molecular nitrogen is sometimes fixed.
The presence of reducing agents in the medium is essential.
There are no specific requirements for vitamins of microelements.
Mesophiles.
Temperature optimum of 25-30°C. growth may occur at 2°C.
The cells contain cytochrome c and b.
Desulfoviridin is absent.
Habitat: anaerobic regions in reservoirs, stratal waters of oil-bearing deposits.
Type species: Desulfomicrobium baculatus.
